```suggestion
CMD=$(git submodule status)
```

If this script reports submodules which should be _deleted_, it should not list nested ones.
nit: `if test -n "$CMD"; then` seems more explicit.\nnit: curly braces are redundant here.

```suggestion
    echo "$CMD"
```

...otherwise, script will print multiple submodules in a line.
Why? Submodule is submodule?

If an "outer" submodule will be deleted, the nested submodule will be deleted automatically (as it resides in the subdirectory of the "outer" submodule), no?\n\nIt seems no need in "delete them" instruction to a user point to nested submodules.
